Initially, the capacitor is uncharged and both switches are open. Switch <math alttext="S sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> is then closed at time <math alttext="t equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>, while Switch <math alttext="S sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> remains open.

(a)

i. Starting with an appropriate application of Kirchhoff’s loop rule, derive, but do NOT solve, a differential equation that could be used to find the charge <math alttext="Q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Q</mi></math> on the capacitor as a function of time <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi></math> after Switch <math alttext="S sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> is closed. After Switch <math alttext="S sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> has been closed a long time, it is opened again. Switch <math alttext="S sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> is then closed.

iii. For times after Switch <math alttext="S sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> is closed, indicate whether the magnitude of the current in the resistor of resistance <math alttext="R sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>R</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> increases, decreases, or remains the same. Justify your answer using physics principles, without deriving or manipulating equations.

Both switches are then closed. The figure also shows point <math alttext="P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi></math>, located just above the battery with <math alttext="e m f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>emf</mi></math> <math alttext="uppercase script E over 5" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><mi>Ɛ</mi><mn>5</mn></mfrac></math>.
(b) Derive an expression for the current at point <math alttext="P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi></math>.
